awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of an Atomic Force Microscope for Fundamental Research in Engineering, Biochemistry and Biology at Gonzaga University
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation award supports the acquisition of a state-of-the-art atomic force microscope (AFM) at Gonzaga University, which provides the ability to accurately measure nanoscale features, deformations and forces, as well as surface chemical and mechanical properties. These capabilities enable fundamental scientific investigations in a myriad of multi-disciplinary research areas at Gonzaga, which include tip-based nanoscale additive manufacturing, nanoscale tribology and materials science, biological imaging and organismal biomechanics. The knowledge generated from this research could catalyze development of novel advanced nanostructured materials and new nanoscale manufacturing methods for sensors and devices. Research on biophysical macromolecular interactions could lead to a new understanding of how biological and ecological systems function. The AFM will be integrated into the curriculum to involve undergraduate students in multidisciplinary, experimental nanoscience and hands-on undergraduate research. The instrument will enhance Gonzaga University's outreach efforts within the greater Spokane and Eastern Washington area, including collaborative partnerships with regional schools, universities and local industry. Student involvement through industry partnerships directly contributes to enhancing skills of future generations of the U.S. workforce.

This AFM is capable of imaging samples of various sizes while maintaining a lateral and vertical resolution of < 0.1nm, and a force resolution of < 100pN in both normal and lateral directions. The AFM is furthermore equipped to allow measurements in static or continuous liquid flow at precisely controlled temperatures (within 1 degree C and up to 300 degrees C) as well as performing accurate nanomechanical and electrical conductivity measurements. These capabilities will enable the development of a fundamental understanding of the mechanisms (physical and chemical) by which nanoparticles in solution interact with substrates under sliding motion, resulting in the growth of functional nanostructures. These findings will accelerate development of novel nano and microscale electromechanical devices with potential applications in healthcare and automation. Measurements using the AFM will also help to establish fundamental relationships between mechanical properties of nanoscale films that form under sliding motion, and their friction and wear properties. These structure-property relationships will enable the design of advanced lubricant materials, with transformative impact on efficiency and reliability of industrial and transportation systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This project enabled the acquisition of a state-of-the-art atomic force microscope (AFM) at Gonzaga University, a primarily undergraduate, research-active university. The acquisition has increased research productivity through greater engagement of undergraduate students in research, as well as the enabling of new interdisciplinary projects by faculty in the College of Arts & Science and the School of Engineering & Applied Science. Research enabled by the AFM include a project to develop a fundamental understanding of polymer nanocomposite wear behavior, a systematic study on early enamel degradation, studying surface characteristics of medical device materials when exposed to disinfectants, and studying surfaces that are stridulated to make sound in rhinoceros beetles. Subsequent to training on the AFM, undergraduate students conducted the bulk of experimental data collection and analysis. Products of these research projects have been presented at numerous local, national and international research conferences and symposia, and are the focus of several peer-reviewed scientific manuscripts (with undergraduate students as first-authors). Students who led these projects have gone to careers in industry, doctoral graduate school and dental schools.

The AFM has also enabled faculty to develop new advanced courses and course modules, resulting in the broadening of curricular offerings available to Gonzaga undergraduate students. For example, the AFM has allowed a greater depth of instruction in a engineering courses on surface science and metrology, as well as nanomanufacturing. Upper division biochemistry courses have also utilized AFM theory and images to enhance student understanding of biological processes that occur on DNA surfaces. Additionally, this AFM has allowed for novel measurements and analyses for projects part of the engineering capstone design, which are often based on real-world engineering applications. Finally, this instrument has provide new and innovative ways for Gonzaga University faculty to contribute to novel science and engineering collaborations with regional industries in manufacturing and materials science.


Last Modified: 02/27/2023
Modified by: Harmandeep Khare
